key_insight: A single pretrained AlphaTensor-Quantum model can be reused (without retraining) to optimize T-counts across a broad family of quantum circuits, producing larger T-count reductions and demonstrating generalizable, efficient circuit optimization.
problem_solved: Reducing the costly T-gate count in quantum circuits typically requires retraining or bespoke optimizers for each circuit class; this work solves the scalability and generalization problem by enabling a single model to optimize many circuit types without retraining.
method: Reuse a pretrained AlphaTensor-Quantum model as a drop-in optimizer for new circuit families, avoiding costly retraining.
Extend the pipeline to handle general circuit structures via modular preprocessing (decomposition, pattern extraction) and cost-aware rewrite rules focused on minimizing T-count.
Run targeted search/rewriting guided by the model to propose and validate transformations that reduce T usage while preserving functionality.
impact: Makes quantum circuit compilation more efficient and scalable: practitioners can achieve lower T-costs and reduced resource requirements across diverse circuits without retraining, accelerating practical quantum algorithm deployment and hardware experiments.
visual_elements: Before/After bar chart showing T-count reductions for several circuit families (pretrained vs baseline).
Pipeline flowchart: pretrained AlphaTensor-Quantum → preprocessing (decompose/extract patterns) → model-guided rewrites → validated optimized circuit.
Heatmap/table mapping circuit classes to percent T-count reduction to illustrate broad applicability and generalization.
Icon set illustrating 'no retraining' (clock/time saved), 'T-gate' (resource), and 'scalability' (many circuits).
paper_title: Reusability report: Optimizing T count in general quantum circuits with AlphaTensor-Quantum
paper_authors: Remmy Zen, Maximilian Nägele, Florian Marquardt
